newsitem.title: USA: First Enterprise stops Tennessee business.
newsitem.headline: First Enterprise stops Tennessee business.

text.p: First Enterprise Financial Group Inc, a subprime lender for cars, said Thursday it stopped buying contracts in Memphis, Tennessee in the second quarter due to a rising level of personal bankruptcies.
In addition to Tennessee, First Enterprise has operations in Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Virginia, Mississippi and North and South Carolina.
Earlier today, the company reported second quarter earnings fell to $0.16 a share from $0.20 in the year ago period. First half earnings rose to $0.44 from $0.41 last year.

"Our results for the first half of 1997 are encouraging in the light of the non prime credit environment in which we operate," said chairman and chief executive officer Michael Harrington. "Bankruptcies, primarily Chapter 13s, are a drag on earnings and require higher reserve provisions," he said in a news release.
First Enterprise raised its loss reserves in the 1997 second quarter to $1.9 million from $225,000 in the same quarter last year.
Shares of First Enterprise were trading up 3/8 to 7-7/8.
